14.text:
The river Wharfe – one of the greatest rivers
in Yorkshire, flows through some of the most

19.text:
varied landscapes in England. Its name means,
“fast flowing”, and it does for 80 miles

27.text:
from Beckermonds to its confluence with the
River Ouse at Cawood south of York, before

32.text:
flowing in to the Humber Estuary and out into
the North Sea. We’re going to travel its

39.text:
first 40 miles, the Wharfedale that is set
in the deep glacial valley, created over 10,000

46.text:
years ago by a glacier gouging, scouring and
crushing anything in its path, before melting

52.text:
away just past the market town of Otley. If
you are looking for a spectacular rise to

60.text:
the river, you’ll be very disappointed – it
doesn’t have one source, but rises from

66.text:
a series of becks that drain the moors of
Cam Fell. It’s bleak, wild and boggy country

73.text:
– the road running over Fleet Moss and down
to Hawes in Wensleydale is the highest in

78.text:
Yorkshire at 1,934ft. Despite its height the
Romans also built a cross Pennine road right

89.text:
along the tops to link their garrisons in
Lancashire to that at Bainbridge in Wensleydale.

96.text:
Much of this road can still be walked on,
as it is used by the long distance footpath,

101.text:
the Pennine Way, that runs 270 miles from
Edale in Derbyshire to Kirk Yetholm in Scotland.

109.text:
You need a fortnight or more to walk its length…..
Two becks, Oughtershaw and Greenside, merge

117.text:
at Beckermonds to form the Wharfe proper.
The water in these becks has already run for

124.text:
three miles or more before reaching here.
Stand on Beckermonds bridge and watch the

132.text:
waters mingle. This golden brown colour is
caused by the peat the rainwater has seeped

140.text:
through. Oddly for a river it never passes
through a highly industrialised town or city

147.text:
along its entire length. Yet this water will
be the lifeblood for many along its route;

153.text:
whether for farming, fishing, drinking water
or industrial processes such as papermaking

159.text:
in Otley. Sheep are never far away – still
the mainstay of farms along the dale; however

169.text:
any associated textile trades relying upon
wool are now all gone. Before we leave the

177.text:
hamlet of Beckermonds have a wander around.
Like many dales hamlets, the land around here

185.text:
has been farmed by the same families for centuries,
such as by the Foster and Lodge families at

192.text:
Beckermonds. They built these farms and farm
workers cottages, mostly in the 17th and 18th

200.text:
centuries. Although this is the river Wharfe,
we aren’t yet in Wharfedale proper. This

207.text:
upper stretch, 10 or 11 miles in length, is
called Langstrothdale – a former hunting

214.text:
forest. At one time trees would have covered
the whole area – but has been cleared for

221.text:
fuel and farmland. The hamlets seen in this
part, like Beckermonds, grew around forest

228.text:
lodges – places from which hunting parties
would depart to catch wild deer. Behind Beckermonds,

237.text:
you will notice the vast acres of a commercial
forest. There are few plantations along the

242.text:
river, and most are used to supply wood locally
for fencing or for use in housing, such as

247.text:
floorboards and joists. Effort is being made
to have a mix of tree types and also to follow

254.text:
the contours of the land rather than stark
blocks of trees. All this land falls within

262.text:
the Yorkshire Dales National Park – established
in 1954. They work in partnership with the

270.text:
government’s Countryside Agency to help
conserve and enhance the area for all. However,

276.text:
nearly all this land is in private ownership
– although some areas have special protection

282.text:
as Sites of Specific Scientific Interest or
are managed by The National Trust and other

287.text:
groups for its flora or its unique geological
features. Local services are provided both

295.text:
by North Yorkshire County Council and Craven
District Council. One wonders whether there

302.text:
are more “officials” based out of the
dale than farmers in it! Although shallow

309.text:
here, the waters are fast flowing, and make
ideal picnic spots or somewhere to play in

314.text:
the natural pools. Look into the river bottom
to see where the glacier has scarred the rock.

323.text:
The next community passed is Deepdale, notable
for the first road bridge across the Wharfe.

329.text:
Along our journey we’ll only come across
13 road bridges and as many footbridges and

335.text:
stepping stones – if the water isn’t too
high! Man has left another impression upon

343.text:
the land since first coming here, probably
around 5,000 years ago. To see an early artefact

351.text:
your first stop-off point should be the Yockenthwaite
stone circle. It is not the only stone circle

358.text:
we shall see on our journey, but it is the
most accessible – after all it is on flat

363.text:
ground – although across the river from
the road! It is 25ft in diameter and is thought

371.text:
to have been built as a burial mound. Yockenthwaite,
now that’s a strange name! It means “Yogan’s

382.text:
clearing” and is Norse in origin. It came
from invaders from Scandinavia who settled

389.text:
here in the 7th century and is the basis for
many of the village names on the Wharfe and

394.text:
words used in local dialect. It’s this tiny
hamlet that is reached by the packhorse bridge.

405.text:
Moving on a few hundred years, and a mile
downstream, we come to St Michael & All the

410.text:
Angels Church at Hubberholme – again it
is very isolated – but central to the hamlets

416.text:
that it was built to serve in the early 12th
century. You need to go inside as it has a

423.text:
very rare example of a rood loft. These separated
the choir from nave and were where the rood

430.text:
– the crucifix was displayed. They were
abolished by Elizabeth I in 1571, however

438.text:
this one escaped, probably because of its
remote location. It’s 18ft wide and 6ft

446.text:
in depth and was constructed in 1558. From
this position you are looking at the back

454.text:
of it. Go to the alter side to see the quality
of the craftsmanship – it hasn’t been

460.text:
restored – all the paintwork is original.
Enjoy the atmosphere….. look out for the

474.text:
mouseman furniture installed by Robert Thompson
of Kilburn in 1934; The stained glass windows

482.text:
that tell about the dale; The bell dated 1601;
And the unusual heptagonal font. Sit and ponder

497.text:
how this church, so far from the city of Bradford
and seemingly having nothing in common with

503.text:
it, has two connections with it: The parish
forms part of the huge Diocese of Bradford….and

511.text:
if you look at a plaque on the tower – this
is a memorial to Bradford born author and

516.text:
playwright J B Priestley who died in 1984.
Opposite the church stands the George Inn.

525.text:
It may look big from the outside, but in fact
the pub was once only the size of a cottage

530.text:
– its now grown to encompass two! The Church
and the pub were once the focal point of all

538.text:
community life – in fact The George has
combined both: it was once the Vicarage! Come

547.text:
here on the first Monday in January to see
the annual Land Letting. Sixteen acres of

554.text:
steep fellside owned by the church since about
1820, and only suitable for sheep grazing,

560.text:
is let every year to the highest bidder – the
one with the bid when the candle goes out.

568.text:
The vicar is the auctioneer and takes bids
in the bar, called for the night the House

572.text:
of Commons. The Churchwardens sit in the House
of Lords, and take the payment for the winning

579.text:
bid. The money raised goes to the poor of
the parish.
